taskbody.context:
A polynomial trend line is a curved line that often fits well with volatile data.
The equation of the trend line looks like: y = an⋅xn ... + a2⋅x2 + a1⋅x + a0. The numbers a0, a1, a2, ... an are called the coefficiënts of the polynomial and n the order.
The order of the polynomial is determined by the number of oscillations (peaks and valleys) in the data:
1e order, the same as the linear trend line.
2e order, usually only one peak or valley in the line. The line is also called a parabola.
3e order, usually one or two peaks or valleys.
4e order, usually up to three peaks or valleys.
In practice, you will have to experiment with the order to find out which is the best fit.The following example is about the performance (in miles per gallon) of a car at various speeds (in miles per hour).Trendlines.xlsx

step.cmd: Open the practice file and select worksheet Polynomial
Select at Trendline Options: Power Order 3. Let equation and R-squared value be displayed in the chart.
Change the chart title in Performance - Speed.
Add Axis titles and change title Y-axis in Performance (miles/gal) and title X-axis in Speed (miles/hr).
Drag in the chart the equation to an empty place.

result.p: R2 = 0,9664 which means that a 2e order polynomial trend line fits the data very well.
